SEARCH
Package com.sgware.serialsoc

Class SerialSocket

java.lang.Object
com.sgware.serialsoc.SerialSocket
All Implemented Interfaces:
Closeable, AutoCloseable
public class SerialSocket extends Object implements Closeable
A wrapper around Socket that listens for lines of input and ensures all events happen on the same thread. A serial socket represents the server side of the connection between a client and server.

Each time a SerialServerSocket accepts a new socket connection, all of the following events will happen on the thread which called SerialServerSocket.run():

  • SerialSocket's constructor is called on that thread. In the constructor, SerialServerSocket.createReader(Socket) will be called to open a BufferedReader on the socekt's input stream, and SerialServerSocket.createWriter(Socket) will be called to open a BufferedWriter on the socekt's output stream. If the constructor throws an exception, no other events will happen for this socket.
  • onConnect() is called exactly once and before any other events.
  • Each time this socket receives a line of input, its receive method is called with that input as a string.
  • When this socket is closed, either because close() was called or because the client closed the connection, onClose is called exactly once. If the socket is still open, this event provides an opportunity to notify the client that the connection will be closed.
  • After the socket is closed, onDisconnect is called exactly once, and it will always be the last event for this socket. This event provides an opportunity to perform any required cleanup.
Version:
1
Author:
Stephen G. Ware

  • Field Details

    • server

    • socket

  • Constructor Details

    • SerialSocket

      protected SerialSocket(SerialServerSocket server, Socket socket) throws Exception
      Constructs a new serial socket. This constructor should be called from SerialServerSocket.createSocket(Socket), which will always run on the main thread. This constructor calls SerialServerSocket.createReader(Socket) and SerialServerSocket.createWriter(Socket) to create input and output streams for the socket.

      If this constructor throws an exception, none of this socket's events will run.

      Parameters:
      server - the serial server socket that created this serial socket
      socket - the network socket to read from and write to
      Throws:
      Exception - if an exception occurs while constructing this socket

  • Method Details

    • close

      public void close()

      Begins the process of disconnecting this socket. After this method is called, onClose() will run on the main thread and this socket will eventually disconnect.

      It is safe to call this method from any thread; it does not need to be called from the main thread.

      Specified by:
      close in interface AutoCloseable
      Specified by:
      close in interface Closeable

    • onConnect

      protected void onConnect() throws Exception
      This method runs exactly once on the main thread after this socket has been created and before all other events.

      By default, this method does nothing. It is meant to be overridden.

      Throws:
      Exception - if an exception is thrown by the method

    • send

      protected void send(String message) throws Exception
      This method sends a string via this socket's output stream. If the string does not end in a new line character, one will be appended. The output stream will then be flushed.

      This method ignores the IOException thrown if the socket is closed or closes during the write operation.

      Parameters:
      message - the message to send via the socket's output stream
      Throws:
      Exception - if an exception is thrown by the method

    • receive

      protected void receive(String message) throws Exception
      This method is called from the main thread every time a new line of input is read from the socket.

      By default, this method does nothing. It is meant to be overridden.

      Parameters:
      message - the line of input read from the socket
      Throws:
      Exception - if an exception is thrown by the method

    • onClose

      protected void onClose() throws Exception
      This method runs exactly once on the main thread when the socket is closed, which can happen when the close() method is called or when the socket is unexpectedly closed, for example by the client. If the socket was closed via the close() method, the socket will remain open until after this method runs, providing an opportunity to send final messages to the client; however, if the socket was closed unexpectedly nothing can be sent (but send(String) will not throw an exception). After this event and after the socket is definitely closed, onDisconnect() will run.

      By default, this method does nothing. It is meant to be overridden.

      Throws:
      Exception - if an exception is thrown by the method

    • onDisconnect

      protected void onDisconnect() throws Exception
      This method runs exactly once on the main thread after the socket is closed and after all other events for this socket. The socket is definitely disconnected before this method runs. This method provides an opportunity for cleanup.

      By default, this method does nothing. It is meant to be overridden.

      Throws:
      Exception - if an exception is thrown by the method
